message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;

public class ReadCSV {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("file.txt"));
        String line;
        while ((line = br.readLine()) != null) {
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(line, ",");
            String[] words = new String[st.countTokens()];
            int i = 0;
            while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
                words[i++] = st.nextToken().trim();
            }
            System.out.println(Arrays.toString(words));
        }
        br.close();
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: This code reads a file line by line using BufferedReader. For each line, it uses StringTokenizer to split the line into tokens using comma as the delimiter. It then stores each token into an array. The trim() method is used to remove any leading or trailing spaces from the tokens. The array is then printed to the console. This will create a new array for each line in the file. If you want to store all tokens in a single array, you would need to use a dynamic data structure like ArrayList instead of a regular array.
